The correct timeline is: 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6
Blue dye swirls into a bathtub drain amid gentle splashing (1) indicates the beginning of the scene. A door opens, signaling a setting change (2), could be the transition from the previous scene to this location. A man enters a dim lab with a backpack and vacuum, heading to an aquarium (3), sets up the scene for the next part of the event. The speaker says to "smash it to bits," followed by a crashing sound (4), likely indicates an experimental procedure that goes awry. At a chalkboard, he says he has thought for five years about quarks stuck inside a proton (5), provides context for the preceding events. Finally, at the board, he admits the solution worked but was for the wrong problem as soft piano begins (6), marks the end of the scene.

The correct chronological order is option A: 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6 -> 7.
David Tong starts by introducing himself and continues with a discussion on solitons. This is followed by a visual display of a close-up icicle, which leads into a meditation on vortices. Afterward, he performs an action - blowing smoke rings - and an interlude of static noise occurs. A group's debate on charges is then presented, after which Tong delves into personal experiences such as taking long baths and playing football. Finally, he concludes his talk with a statement about the million-dollar problem and the music played during his conclusion gives the video its melancholic feel.
